tn.text: "Behold!" "You should know!" Yahweh tells the people to pay attention.

tn.ref: Yahweh's hand is not so short
tn.text: "Hand" represents power and ability. A "short" hand does not have power and ability. AT: "Yahweh is fully able" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
These plural pronouns refer to the people of Israel as a single group. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

tn.ref: your sins have made him hide his face from you
tn.text: "Face" represents being present and looking upon. AT: "your sins have made him turn away from you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
Isaiah continues speaking to the people of Israel.

tn.ref: For your hands are stained with blood and your fingers with sin
tn.text: Here "hands" and "fingers" refers to their actions. This means they are guilty of doing violent and sinful things. "Your" is plural. AT: "For you have committed violent sins" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

tn.ref: Your lips speak lies and your tongue speaks maliciously
tn.text: The parts of the body that make speech represent what people say. AT: "You speak lies and malicious things" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: they conceive trouble and give birth to sin
tn.text: "Conceiving" and "giving birth" emphasize how carefully they plan to do sinful things. Here "they" still refers to the people of Israel. AT: "they work hard to do sinful things" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Isaiah continues speaking to the people of Israel about the evil they do using the metaphors of poisonous snakes and spider's webs.

tn.ref: They hatch eggs of a poisonous snake
tn.text: Eggs of a poisonous snake hatch into more dangerous snakes. "Poisonous snakes" represents evil the people do that harms more and more. AT: "They make evil that spreads out to make more evil" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This represents the deeds of the people that are useless. AT: "produce things and activities that are useless" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Whoever eats of their eggs dies, and if an egg is crushed, it hatches into a poisonous snake
tn.text: Eating a poisonous egg will kill the one that eats it and represents self-destruction. Breaking the egg allows the young poisonous snake to hatch and represents spreading destruction. AT: "The activities they do will destroy them and will spread destruction to others" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "if someone crushes an egg" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: Their webs cannot be used for garments, nor can they cover themselves with their works
tn.text: This means their sinful deeds cannot be covered and hidden, just as a web cannot serve as clothing and cover someone. AT: "Their evil deeds will be exposed as useless" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Their webs cannot be used for garments
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "They cannot clothe themselves with their webs" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: deeds of violence are in their hands
tn.text: "Hands" represents the ability and power to do these things and therefore their responsibility. AT: "they are fully responsible for the violence they do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Isaiah continues speaking to the people of Israel.
"Feet" represents the ability to go and "run" represents doing it speedily. AT: "They are quick to do evil things" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"roads" represents their way of life. AT: "are all they do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: there is no justice in their paths
tn.text: "paths" represents their way of life. AT: "they never do what is just" or "everything they do is unjust" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"Crooked paths" represents the way of life that is corrupt. AT: "They say and do dishonest things. They are devious" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Isaiah continues speaking to the people of Israel.

Here "us" refers to Isaiah and the people of Israel. "Far" represents that justice is gone and difficult to get. AT: "justice is gone and very difficult to get" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_inclusive]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: We wait for light, but see darkness; we look for brightness, but we walk in darkness
tn.text: Each of these phrases means that the people are waiting for God's goodness, but it seems like he has abandoned them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: We grope for the wall like the blind ... like dead men
tn.text: This means that because God is not coming to them, they feel helpless, not finding the right path and despairing of the future, with no hope for a vibrant life. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
Isaiah continues speaking to the people of Israel.

tn.ref: We growl like bears and moan like doves
tn.text: These refer to the sounds the people made because they were distressed and mourning. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
Isaiah continues speaking.
Here "our" refers to Isaiah and the people of Israel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_inclusive]])
Here "you" refers to Yahweh. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_yousingular]])
Isaiah describes the sins as a person who goes before God to declare that the people are guilty. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: for our transgressions are with us
tn.text: "With us" represents being aware of them. AT: "for we are aware of our transgressions" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Isaiah continues speaking.
This can be stated in active form. TA: "The people drive justice back" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
These are ideas that Isaiah describes as acting like persons. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
Isaiah continues speaking.

tn.ref: He saw that there was no man, and wondered that there was no one to intervene.
tn.text: "Yahweh was appalled that no one came to help those who were suffering." or "Yahweh was astonished that no one came to help those who were suffering."

tn.ref: Therefore his own arm brought salvation for him
tn.text: "arm" represents ability and power. AT: "Yahweh used his own power to save the people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

"Righteousness" is a quality that acts like a person. AT: "and he did right as he always would do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: He put on righteousness as a breastplate and a helmet of salvation upon his head. He clothed himself with garments of vengeance and wore zeal as a mantle
tn.text: "breastplate," "helmet," "garments," and "mantle" are clothing for war and fighting. Isaiah describes Yahweh as putting these on to punish his people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
a loose, flowing robe
Isaiah is describing a future event as if it happened in the past. This means that it will certainly happen.
Isaiah continues speaking.
Here "name" refers to Yahweh's reputation and character. AT: "fear Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: from the west ... from the sun's rising
tn.text: Isaiah combines these words to mean people in all places of the world. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])

tn.ref: for he will come as a rushing stream
tn.text: Narrow valleys in Judah were dry most of the year until a sudden, heavy rain turned them into fast-moving water. When that happened there was a lot of noise and wind. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: driven by the breath of Yahweh
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "which the breath of Yahweh drives" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

This can be reworded so that the abstract noun "declaration" is expressed as the verb "declared" or "solemnly said." Translate this the same way you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:isa:14:21|14:22]]. AT: "this is what Yahweh has declared" or "this is what Yahweh has solemnly said" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: my words which I have put in your mouth
tn.text: This refers to giving someone something to say. AT: "the message I have given you to speak" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
